subject: Re: Should we inject the logger? (Re: [junit] How to test a method that logs to a file)
msgSnippet: I d say do not inject a logger.  Instead inject, or (I preder) use an event to notify, an interface that makes sense with respect to the object s domain.
messageBody:
I'd say do not inject a logger. Instead inject, or (I preder) use an event
to notify, an interface that makes sense with respect to the object's
domain. Then, implement that with logging where necessary.

Most of the time, logging is a very different concern to that of the
object's main functionality and so should be decoupled from the object.
That allows the object to be used in different contexts more easily.

As an example of why logging should be decoupled, look at the Apache HTTP
Client library. That uses commons logging to log progress and errors, which
makes sense in a server process but does force you to add commons logging to
the classpath. However, it makes no sense at all in an application with a
GUI. In a GUI application I want to display progress notifications in the
status bar and error notifications into a dialog box (or somewhere more
helpful). I also don't want to include a logging library into the
application and have to configure it to *not* create output.

--Nat

On 09/11/2007, J. B. Rainsberger <jbrains762@...> wrote:
>
> Stephen Smith wrote:
> >
> >
> > Use the Dependency Injection pattern to inject your Logger into your
> > class, and then use JMock or a similar mocking API
> > to assert that the logger is called with your expected parameters.
>
> An interesting question: should we really inject the Logger? If we did
> that everywhere, then everything would depend on Logger. Is that wise?
